channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: New York Plans New Nuclear Plant as Energy Demand Surges
item.description: New York state is pushing to build a nuclear power plant to meet growing demand for clean energy, the first major US reactor project in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Will Wade, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: A cooling tower at the Nine Mile Point Nuclear Station in Scriba, New York.

item.title: Gold Rises as Iran Pledges Retaliation for US Military Strikes
item.description: Gold rose as Israel ratcheted up attacks on Iran on Monday while Tehran vowed to retaliate against US military strikes of nuclear facilities in the Islamic Republic.
item.dc:creator: Elise Harris

media:content.media:description: The escalation of hostilities has given fresh impetus to a rally that’s pushed gold up almost 30% so far this year. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Tanker Rates Soar to Highest Since 2023 After US Bombs Iran
item.description: Tanker rates extended gains as tensions in the Middle East ratchet higher, with shipowners demanding bigger fees to call at ports in the Persian Gulf after the US launched strikes on Iran over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Tankers are seen at the Khor Fakkan Container Terminal, the only natural deep-sea port in the region and one of the major container ports in the Sharjah Emirate, along the Strait of Hormuz, a waterway through which one-fifth of global oil output passes on June 23, 2025. (Photo by Giuseppe CACACE / AFP) (Photo by GIUSEPPE CACACE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Emerging Currencies Pare Drop as Dollar Wavers on Fed, Mideast
item.description: Developing-nation currencies pared losses as investors weighed the next steps for US interest rates and tensions in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

item.title: Stocks Fall After Report About Iran Retaliation: Markets Wrap
item.description: A rebound in stocks sputtered as oil rose, with investors concerned about a potential Iranian response to US attacks on its nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Oil storage containers in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Oil steadied following its biggest one-day jump in almost a year as fears that Israel may decide to strike Iranian crude facilities in retaliation for a missile barrage kept the market on edge.

item.title: US Bonds Rise as July Rate-Cut Bets Grow, Traders Seek Havens
item.description: Treasuries rose after another Federal Reserve official hinted that an interest-rate cut could come as soon as next month, extending gains stoked by haven demand after the US bombed nuclear sites in Iran over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: Oil tankers sit anchored off the coast of Long Beach, California, U.S., on Wednesday, April 22, 2020. Almost three dozen ships -- scattered in waters from Long Beach to the San Francisco Bay -- are mostly acting as floating storage for oil that's going unused as the coronavirus pandemic shutters businesses and takes drivers off the road.

item.title: Pantera's Morehead Says Equities 'Rich,' Favors Crypto
item.description: Pantera Capital founder and Managing Partner Dan Morehead says equity valuations are a bit rich compared to bonds and explains why he likes crypto over gold on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Swings as Iran War Escalates and Trump Calls for Low Prices
item.description: Oil fluctuated as traders wrestled with US President Donald Trump’s call for lower prices amid signs of further escalation in the conflict with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: Smoke from the Shahran oil depot, following a missile strike northwest of Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Extent of Damage to Iran Nuclear Sites Unknown
item.description: The US is pushing for Iran to come back to the negotiating table, but Iranian officials say airstrikes against the country need to stop. Meanwhile, the extent of damage to Iran's nuclear facilities is unclear. Bloomberg's Tyler Kendall reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Qatar Closes Airspace as Iran Crisis Impact on Airlines Mounts
item.description: Qatar suspended its air traffic as a precautionary measure in response to the regional armed conflict, effectively halting operations of its namesake airline after the US struck nuclear sites in Iran and Tehran vowed to retaliate.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/23/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Warns Against Rising Oil Prices Following Iran Attack
item.description: President Donald Trump demanded that energy producers push down crude prices following US military strikes on Iran, amid fears that an escalating Middle East conflict and supply disruptions could extend the recent surge on oil markets.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Tyler Kendall, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks in Sealy, Texas.

item.title: Holcim North American Spinoff Amrize Slips in Trading Debut
item.description: Amrize Ltd.’s shares fell in Switzerland following the North American cement-maker’s spinoff from Holcim Ltd, as the building materials conglomerate looks to unlock value through a separate listing.
item.dc:creator: Allegra Catelli

media:content.media:description: A Holcim AG logo during the groundbreaking ceremony of the Holcim GO4ZERO net-zero cement plant in Obourg, Belgium, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Holcim is going ahead with the net-zero cement plant set to produce 2 million tons of product per year by 2029. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Majors Cut Back Iraq Personnel as Mideast Tensions Rise
item.description: BP Plc, TotalEnergies SE and Eni SpA have reduced staff at oil fields in Iraq as a precaution, as tensions escalate in the region.
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Ferman, Khalid Al Ansary

media:content.media:description: The North Rumaila gas field southern Iraqi port of Basra. Photographer: Haidar Mohammed Ali/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: S&P 500 Edges Higher as Traders Assess Impact of Strike on Iran
item.description: US stock moves were subdued on Monday following a US attack on Iranian nuclear sites over the weekend as traders speculated the escalation would remain contained.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Tesla Shares Jump Most in Two Months on Robotaxi Service Launch
item.description: Tesla Inc. shares surged after the automaker rolled out its long-promised driverless taxi service to a handful of riders, a modest debut for what Elon Musk sees as a transformative new business line.
item.dc:creator: Kara Carlson

media:content.media:description: A Tesla robotaxi vehicle in Austin on June 22.

item.title: Romania Unveils $6.8 Billion Fiscal Plan as Cabinet Approved
item.description: Romania’s new government unveiled plans to scale back the budget deficit by 30 billion lei ($6.8 billion) this year as part of a broader package that may involve a one-off bank levy and pension and wage caps.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

item.title: Fed’s Bowman Says ‘Time Has Come’ to Reform Key Capital Rule
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman warned the current approach to leverage ratio requirements has led to unintended consequences in the market while adding she could support lowering interest rates as soon as July.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve Michelle Bowman

item.title: Enbridge Eyes Adding Pipeline Space for Oil Flows to Gulf Coast
item.description: Enbridge Inc. and partner Energy Transfer LP are gauging interest in increased pipeline capacity in Illinois that would carry more crude to markets on the US Gulf Coast.
item.dc:creator: Lucia Kassai

media:content.media:description: The sun rises beyond oil storage tanks at the Enbridge Inc. Cushing storage terminal in Cushing, Oklahoma, U.S., on Wednesday, March 25, 2015. The fastest oil-inventory growth on record at the main U.S. hub may be about to end, easing concern that storage limits will be strained. Photographer: Daniel Acker

item.title: Lazard's Temple Says It's Too Risky to Chase Stocks Now
item.description: Lazard Chief Market Strategist Ron Temple says it is too risk to chase stocks either positively or negatively right now amid the geopolitical tensions. He speaks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Iran's Regime Is Still Dangerous, Says Esper
item.description: Mark Esper, former US Defense Secretary, says Iran's regime is still dangerous and could respond to the US airstrikes. He also talks about 900 pounds of missing uranium from Iran, the capability of the US military and what could happen if Iran tries to close the Strait of Hormuz. He speaks on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Corrects spelling of guest's name in headline.) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nagel Says ECB Can’t Commit on Rates Given High Uncertainty
item.description: The European Central Bank shouldn’t commit to a certain interest-rate path, given how US trade policy and the situation in the Middle East are clouding the outlook, according to Governing Council member Joachim Nagel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt.

item.title: Irish Regulator Resists Pressure to Ease Bank Regulation
item.description: Ireland’s top banking supervisor warned of a need to stick with high standards of financial regulation particularly now when there is increasing pressure to ease them amid trade wars, geopolitical tensions and fears for global growth.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher, Laura Noonan

item.title: Meat Giant JBS Plans First Bond Sale After US Listing to Extend Debt Maturities
item.description: JBS NV is preparing to sell bonds for the first time after its US listing as the world’s largest meat producer seeks to extend maturities on its debt.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: Cattle trucks offload livestock at the JBS Greeley meatpacking facility in Greeley, Colorado, US, on Friday, Feb. 28, 2025. Plans for the biggest deportations in US history threaten to upend the meatpacking industry.

item.title: US Home Resales Stay Sluggish on Affordability Constraints
item.description: US previously owned home sales rose slightly in May to a still-sluggish pace that continues to show a housing market constrained by poor affordability.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

item.title: Lagarde Reiterates ECB Well Placed But Monitoring Oil Swings
item.description: The European Central Bank is well placed to tackle “exceptionally high” uncertainty but will closely watch gyrations in commodities markets as tensions in the Middle East flare, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: Fed’s Bowman: Time Has Come to Revisit Leveraged Ratios
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman warns that the current approach to leverage ratio requirements has led to unintended consequences in the market. She speaks at a research conference sponsored by the International Journal of Central Banking and the Czech National Bank.

item.title: Wolfspeed Plans Bankruptcy After Clinching Deal With Creditors
item.description: Wolfspeed Inc. is planning to file for bankruptcy by July 1 with a deal to slash its debt by about $4.6 billion and hand over control to convertible noteholders.
item.dc:creator: Georgia Hall, Jonathan Randles, Steven Church

media:content.media:description: A Wolfspeed wafer Photographer: Boris Roessler/picture alliance/Getty Images

item.title: Dollar Erases Gain as Fed’s Bowman Signals Support for July Cut
item.description: The dollar erased its advance on Monday after the Federal Reserve’s Michelle Bowman said she could support reducing interest rates as soon as July.
item.dc:creator: Anya Andrianova, Naomi Tajitsu

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: Pound Fluctuates, Oil Falls as Markets Assess US Strikes on Iran
